Award.AwardTitle: REU site: Integrative approaches to studying recognition systems in cells, organisms, and populations.
Award.AbstractNarration: An award was made to the Biology Department at Tufts University to provide research training for 10 weeks for 10 students per year, for the summers of 2013-2015. The summer program is entitled, " Integrative approaches to studying recognition systems in cells, organisms, and populations" and will provide students the opportunity to work closely on collaborative, interdisciplinary projects combining faculty expertise in biochemistry, genetics, development, endocrinology, neurobiology, animal behavior, plant ecology, and conservation biology. Students will work with two mentors, one serving as the primary mentor, to combine research techniques from different fields to design and conduct an independent project. In addition to research involvement, the program includes weekly discussions, seminars, field trips, and a student symposium. The goals of this summer program are to increase students' proficiency in biological research and collaborative skills, to educate and inspire students toward future research careers, and to develop students' ability to effectively communicate scientific results. Accordingly, seminars are focused on proficiency in science/communication of scientific results, scientific ethics/responsible conduct of research, and career development. We select our participants from a broad undergraduate applicant pool, and the program is committed to providing research opportunities for students traditionally underrepresented in science and those who might not have such opportunities at their home institutions (with an emphasis on community college students). The Tufts University Department of Biology has a long-standing commitment to mentoring undergraduates in research, and a strong track record of highly productive interdisciplinary research collaborations. Student-mentor relationships typically extend long beyond the research experience and are facilitated via electronic networking tools. The participants provide frequent feedback on the program, and thus take an active role in refining the approach. Information about the program will be assessed by various means, including use of an REU common assessment tool. For more information, contact Phil Starks at REU@tufts.edu and visit our webpage http://ase.tufts.edu/biology/undergraduate/research/reu.htm.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Science depends on continued input and innovation, and to enable this we must train the next generation of scientists. A potential barrier is the 'identity' issue: it can be challenging for students to see themselves as scientists. We address this issue in our 10-week summer NSF funded research experience for undergraduates (REU) program by enabling students to experience, first hand, all aspects of the scientific process.

We have a large and expanding general biology department at Tufts University. The focus of our REU Site Program is recognition systems. Placing projects within the umbrella of recognition systems reinforces the continuity of biological research and allows students to explore a diverse array of systems using a diverse array of techniques.

Between 2013 and 2015 (the initial years for this proposal) we received almost 600 applicants for 30 positions. 60% of our participant pool over that period self-identified as belonging to historically underrepresented groups. Four additional students received training due to an extension of this grant. Our participants came from colleges from across the country and formed scientific communities on our Medford campus. In total, our faculty mentored 34 students and allowed them to explore interests for biological fields ranging from molecular biology to population dynamics.

To accomplish our main goal of providing a high quality research experience, we train our students to be independent scientists, promote a sense of community, foster project ownership, and provide career development tools. To reach these specific goals, we:

  • provide resources necessary to facilitate inclusion into the local community, train participants in the conceptual techniques necessary to become independent researchers (i.e., how to design projects then collect, analyze, and present data), and teach the communication skills critical to success in science;
  • promote a sense of community within which our students can excel by taking our students on educational field trips, providing weekly working dinner meetings, housing them together on campus, and inviting them into our homes;
  • instill in students a feeling of project ownership by having them present a mid-program talk and lead lab tours;
  • discuss identifying appropriate graduate programs, help them construct a resume, and introduce them to a panel of scientists that work in a diversity of fields to help our students understand a path forward in science.

In addition to general scientific and field-specific training, our participants received financial support (including housing) and career development advice, cumulating in an alternative careers in science panel discussion that included educators, health care practitioners, and representatives from governmental organizations, non-governmental organizations, and industry.

Our students' responses to survey questions indicated that they reaped significant scientific gains from participation in our program. Of our 34 students, about a third are working in research, ~30% are in graduate school (including 10% in dual degree programs), ~20% have just recently graduated and/or applying for programs, and ~15% are pursuing heath care careers. Many of our participants have been authors on conference posters, presentations, and/or peer-reviewed publications, and several more are authors on manuscripts that are in preparation.
